Trust me, I've read the book and I loved it. I feel as if Laura Hillenbrand, author of Unbroken, should have directed it but that's my opinion. I'm not rating the movie anything yet as we all have to make our assumptions over one trailer. I do have high hopes for the movie and I hope Jolie knows that a lot of other people do as well.  We'll see ladies and gentlemen. We'll see.

text: I am worried about this film. The reason I am worried is that I am not familiar with Ms. Jolies directing abilities or her ability to tell a good story. With a movie that features something that is so rarely seen (The Japanese Prisoner of war Camps) I hope that it is shown as the true hell that it was. Does this mean the movie will be bad, no I'm not saying that. Should we question the quality of the film because it's directed by Jolie? no we shouldn't. I simply am spreading my concern as someone who wants to see this movie be a great and powerful film and not just a flop.

text: It's sad to know that more people are focused on who directed it and how superficial the story is than on the fact that this is a story about someone who, along with thousands of others, had to offer up their lives, no matter how successful, for a brutal war. A war intensified by the savagery of the Japanese soldiers, whom POWs had to endure under the conditions of disease, starvation, and grueling labor. Even the European POWs were not so mistreated, and it's a miracle that Louis Zamperini, among his brothers in arms, managed to live to tell the tale.

text: This trailer was so amazing. Perfect pacing. Build up. Cut aways to scenes matching narration etc. Everything hitting all the right notes. I just love the ending. Music starts kicking (great melodic emotional music btw) "Only courage can you bring home"... ¬†"stay down" ...and then it culminates with the dude holding the wood refusing to let it drop "refusing to 'stay down'". No matter what, never give up etc. His emotion too. Wow. ¬†That looks like its going to be a powerful scene. He looks like a great actor. This trailer literally gives me chills. Im really looking forward to Unbroken. Its been a long time since theres been a truly great inspirational movie. I hope its as amazing as this trailer was. text: I love how some people think that America is such a savage nation. We developed the atomic bomb and used it as a last-resort attempt to end a brutal war before it could have become even more bloody with a mainland invasion of Japan. After WWII was over, we literally were the only superpower on Earth and could have used our resources to crush the rest of the planet and become its supreme rulers, but we DIDN'T. Instead, we supplied the majority funds to rebuild Europe with the Marshall plan and then protected Western Europe from the Soviet Union for decades thereafter. That is not the mark of a savage. That is the mark of a civilized people. In countries with Islam as the law of the land, however, "infidels" are executed in legal honor killings and women are treated like cattle. Is this the mark of a more civilized people?

text: I wish someone would make a film about how neoliberalism has betrayed democracy and all those who fought to defend it.  Here is a letter from a 90 yr. old British WWII veteran:  "We have somehow broken our solemn bond with those warriors of yesterday and forgotten that when the survivors of the Second World War returned to their homes, they were like a tide that raised all boats. My generation's shared experience of suffering, of witnessing genocide, ethnic cleansing, and enduring unspeakable privations as both soldiers and civilians made us vigilant when it came to demanding our peace dividend. We knew what we deserved and that was a future that didn't resemble our hard-scrabble past. The Green and Pleasant land was for everyone after the war because we had bled for it and died for it. We demanded a truly democratic society where merit was rewarded and no one would be left behind because of poverty, poor health or an inadequate education.  Today, however, in a world where our reservoirs of wealth are as deep and enormous as all the mighty rivers of the world combined, our politicians, financial institutions and megalithic industries tell us we can no longer afford these human rights that men sacrificed their lives for: the freedom to live with dignity in a compassionate society. We are told by those in charge that we can no longer live with luxuries like healthcare, proper state funded pensions, decent wages, trade unions and most aspects of our social safety network.  At 90, I am too old to take up the fight, too old to stand in demonstrations with a placard denouncing this madness. All I can do is bear witness to my times and our heroic struggle fought so long ago against Hitler and against men who would wreck the foundations that made civilisation tolerable and decent for its inhabitants.  The problem with society, today, is not lack of money or debt but lack of ideas, lack of commitment by our government to realise that its constituents are the people, not city bankers and hedge fund managers whose loyalty is to their ledger books rather than to the community. I don't know if we will come out of this present darkness. Perhaps humanity will simply retreat into the caves whence our ancestors came because we were cowed by self-serving political parties and dubious leaders of business. I hope not, for the sake of the generations to come, but there is one thing I am certain of: had the politicians and business mandarins of today been in power in 1939, they wouldn't have had the bottle to fight Nazism. There would have been no Dunkirk, no Battle of Britain, no Finest Hour. Our leaders today on either side of the house would have allowed the lights across Europe to grow dim, because after all that would have been the cheapest and most prudent solution to Hitler's tyranny."  http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/may/09/is-camerons-britain-what-we-fought-for

text: I rarely write a comment on YouTube, but now I need to, after reading some of the misleading comments and disputes here.  - I will only focus on past wars. We all hate war and should work toward peace. But, that doesn't mean that we should forget about the past; we should constantly learn from the past to make a better future. I won't talk more on "how" we should see history, since we can go on and on and have another huge discussion about it.  - I agree that all countries, including Japan, Germany, US, and Korea, have their ugly sides when it comes to war. We all know about the inhumane acts done by some American soldiers in Iraq, and we all know about the Holocaust. I'm Korean, and I'm also aware of the violence and killings done by the Korean soldiers during the Vietnam War. And I believe that we should make a sincere apology and appropriate compensation to Vietnam, just like Japan should to Korea and other countries/peoples they so inhumanely obliterated. But again, I won't talk about the whole bunch of what is "sincere" and "appropriate" here. At least, I believe that many would agree that what German government has done - both to the victims and to themselves - to compensate for what their previous generations had committed would be considered closest to such "sincerity" and "appropriateness." Today's general atmosphere in Germany toward the WW2 is self-reflection. On the other hand, the general atmosphere in Japan seems to be ignorance, as their history textbooks prove. (This is why I tend to differentiate between "Germany" and "Nazi" but not between "Japan" and the "Imperial Japanese government" in casual discussions.)  - Although no countries are innocent, that doesn't mean that we should stop shedding light on the Japanese atrocities, such as this movie. Rather, we should shed more light, but not on just one war or one country. Meanwhile, I think we should shed more and more light on the Japanese atrocities because people worldwide, especially in Europe and America, are too unaware of these, compared to their awareness of Nazi Germany. I find this very ironic and unfortunate because what Japan had done is no less, perhaps worse, than what the Nazis had done. Japan often may seem to be "nicer" compared to the Nazis because they didn't target on single race to cleanse. Although the concept of "race cleansing" is horrible, I think what matters more here is "what" they did than "whom" they did to. If you can, spare 30 minutes of your day searching for such barbarity, such as live human dissections (including pregnant women and their babies), rape, massacre, and that smile in the faces of the soldiers, each holding a head that he cut off from an innocent civilian. Then, you will understand that there are hundreds of more "true stories" just waiting to be told, that need to told, not only for those who've been innocently killed and their loved ones taken away but also for our future generations.  - I've seen some people (even here) denying the Japanese atrocities in Korea, saying that Koreans were "accepted" as "their people," that the same laws applied, and that Korean men fought against Americans for Japan. All of these arguments are either false or meaningless however. The truth is that Koreans were oppressed in all possible ways. One of the most vicious and inhumane acts committed by the Japanese was erasing the Korean identity. Koreans were forced to change their names into Japanese; whoever spoke Korean, including boys and girls, were beaten; books in Korean were burned; history was erased; buildings and other cultural and historical monuments were torn down, etc. Although such cultural violence is not the first in human history, that does not make the Japanese atrocity any less evil. True acceptance comes from accepting the others' own distinct identity, whether that be individual or group identity. Moreover, beside from all the horrendous oppressions, the fact that the Japanese took the country away by force was the greatest violence to the Koreans. The entire nation had constantly fought for independence during the colonial period. No matter how "accepting" or "nice" the Japanese were, a forceful colonization itself was an atrocity.  Peace

text: These comments are pathetic. This movie was not made to glorify the US or make Japan look bad, it was made to tell how Louie survived. If all you got from this trailer is that America is bad, then there is something wrong with you. I am American, and guess what, I know my country has made mistakes, but you want to know something else? Every country has. Every person has. Don't let the actions of a few corrupt soldiers shape your views of an entire country. Don't take such an inspirational movie like this and ruin it by turning it into something it's not. I read this book, and it was amazing. They wanted to keep it PG-13, so you won't even know some of the crap he went through unless you read the book. Now let's all grow up and stop insulting other countries. With your insults, you are accomplishing nothing except for making your own country look arrogant and stupid. I'm not going to say the US is the best country in the world, but it is not nearly as bad as what many of you are saying.

text: I can't believe how people are being such bigots about this movie! ¬†It's all about the human spirit. ¬†When people tell you no you can't do it and you do everything you can to prove them wrong. ¬†It's not about him being an American or him being tortured by a Japanese soldier, but the fact that he didn't give up because it was in his nature. ¬†When he says, "If You get me through this, I swear, I'll dedicate my whole life to You" He's talking about God and becoming a follower of Christ.  After he is tortured and released from the P.O.W., he thinks about vengeance and wanting to kill the man who tortured him for everything he put him through. ¬†Then finds faith in God and believes in forgiveness. ¬†He wants to find the soldier that tortured him and show him love, compassion, and mercy...even though most people in society would say otherwise and do the opposite. ¬†He goes to look for him after the war and discovers that the Japanese soldier who had tortured him, killed himself because he was in such shame of what he did to people during the war. ¬†  So while people want to continue arguing and bickering, just consider what he did and that love is the answer to everything. ¬†Not this constant hate of what humanity is known for, but for going above and beyond.

text: I love how several top commentators on this video are referring to Americans as "White scum." Grow up. Accusing Americans of being racist? Your comments are racist. You can not stereotype a culture based on what they did in the past. Those people are dead and gone. That kind of stereotyping leads to racism and wars (fyi). So stop being hypocritical, suck it up, and model yourself after the West, because that is the measuring stick of a countries success in this day and age. Is that unfortunate? Maybe so, but insulting American will not cover up the fact that we are the most powerful country on earth and we got to where we are because we love conquest (among other things) (That is a cultural tendency by the way, not an ethnic one). Is that bad? Maybe so, but do not complain if your country is not the same way and does not follow those principles, because they are tried and true. Successful countries follow a Western model. China. Japan. South Korea. United States. Brazil (getting there). Etc. etc. That is my opinion, yours may differ. text: What the hell guys? I read all of these comments on how Japan is evil bc of this or how america is horrible for all of that. Let me give you two sides on this. I'm half Japanese and half american. I was born in California raised half of my life in Japan and currently in America getting my bachelors degree in Japanese American history. I know both sides. I read extensively on Japanese warlords during WW2 and American history of Pearl Harbor. I also read this book 2 and wrote a full analysis on it. This book isn't about race or rising conflict of WW2. This is an inspirational book/ movie about how this man survived through such a horrible experience. Now I'm not going to say that Japanese isn't wrong for all of this. They are. But they know that. All of the people I interviewed about Pearl Harbor, the Japanese and American survivors all had their peace with it. They don't still have a long living grudge on Americans or Japanese. My mother who was born and raised in japan cried when she went to the Pearl Harbor museum. She was horrified on how many people died. So all of this crap people are saying about how bad Japanese are. Stop it. Also all this crap about how America is bad. Stop it. And all of this crap about how this rises ongoing conflicts about Japan and America STOP IT. It isn't worth it bc its just a kid trying to survive. And inspirations movie of never giving up. So chill out

text: This movie was nothing less of greatness in documenting a man‚Äôs life so epic on all human capacity. Louis fought with peace and integrity not just for his family, friends or his enemies, but for humanity. We will all die at some point in our lifetime; what do you want the world to remember you as? Despite, many critics and their open opinions about the film, we can't deny the bravery that exist within this film of which depicted Louis Zamperini and many who illuminated his life. Throughout this movie his life broadcast many struggles beyond war, beyond men, beyond race, beyond countries‚Äô borders, but of deep faith beyond persecution. ¬†We can only image someone else‚Äôs pain until we have walked in their shoes. Unbroken has taught me to never let someone still your joy and forgive, not just for the other person, but mostly for you. ¬†

text: Unbroken. Disappointed. For Jolie's FIRST movie, it was quite an achievement. I could see what she wanted to portray, but she didn't capture it. This is a movie made for children to watch to overcome obstacles. Should have been produced by Disney. No dialogue. She needs to take notes from Ron Howard and Clint Eastwood as she attempted to bring a script (missing a lot) into the light. It's portrayed like a documentary without any dates. It would have been nice to see a timeline of dates on the screen. What town was he raised and year? What year were the Olympics he was in? Didn't mention Hitler was a fan of his and he even shook his hand. (as it would make movie goers ponder how in 1936 Berlin hosted the Olympics, while they invaded the majority of European countries and Japan were set to do it in 1940 for a nice correlation of events and he was captured literally just before the bombing of Pearl Harbor to start WWII) It failed to mention he spent 45 days at sea, the screen only showed 28 days. Just disappointed. It alluded a lot of reference to God and his religious faith, but failed to mention that because of his turning to Christ while at Sea, he endured the next 2 years of POW camps because of his faith in the Lord and later became one of the most well respected and known evangelist's in America. Seems like on the editing room floor everyone just said "Yup, thats a great idea" huff. Waiting on American Sniper Jan 16th. Wait for this movie on Netflix people.¬†And seriously who DOESN"T attempt to escape while being held captive. He was sitting at a restaurant by himself in Japan.....smh, I would have cut that part out. Not Army approved.Ôªø

text: This is a quote by Winston Churchill (Prime Minister of the UK from 1940-1945), referring to the day when President Roosevelt told him the United States was attacked by Japan (Pearl Harbor) which meant that the US now had to enter the war.¬†   >>>>>>>>>>In two or three minutes Mr. Roosevelt came through. "Mr. President, what's this about Japan? "It's quite true," he replied. "They have attacked us at Pearl Harbor. We are all in the same boat now."  No American will think it wrong of me if I proclaim that to have the United States at our side was to me the greatest joy. I could not foretell the course of events. I do not pretend to have measured accurately the martial might of Japan, but now at this very moment I knew the United States was in the war, up to the neck and in to the death. So we had won after all!  Yes, after Dunkirk; after the fall of France; after the horrible episode of Oran; after the threat of invasion, when, apart from the Air and the Navy, we were an almost unarmed people; after the deadly struggle of the U-boat war‚Äîthe first Battle of the Atlantic, gained by a hand's-breath; after seventeen months of lonely fighting and nineteen months of my responsibility in dire stress. We had won the war. England would live; Britain would live; the Commonwealth of Nations and the Empire would live.  How long the war would last or in what fashion it would end no man could tell, nor did I at this moment care. Once again in our long Island history we should emerge, however mauled or mutilated, safe and victorious. We should not be wiped out. We should not be wiped out. Our history would not come to an end. We might not even have to die as individuals. Hitler's fate was sealed. Mussolini's fate was sealed. As for the Japanese, they would be ground to powder.<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<    So, THANK YOU America for coming in, not only in this war, but the first World War. Thank you because without you who knows how the world would look like today!!
author: Camila Valdez

text: And also, guess what America did after winning the war??¬† This is what America did afterwards: Japan>>>>> "The American Occupation in Japan was a historical success story. During the seven year occupation from 1945 until 1952, the Americans restructured the Japanese government and gave Japan the footing after its post WWII demise. The Occupation provided the groundwork from which one of the strongest nations of the 20th century emerged by laying the foundation for democracy and successful capitalism. On a ideological level, the American occupation was intended to instill democratic values and eradicate imperialist ways. On a practical level, the American occupation was intended to disarm the military, break up the zaibatsu businesses, reform the educational system, give power to the local level, and give women suffrage"   Europe>>>>> "The Marshall Plan (officially the European Recovery Program, ERP) was the American initiative to aid Europe, in which the United States gave $17 billion (approximately $160 billion in current dollar value) in economic support to help rebuild European economies after the end of World War II. The plan was in operation for four years beginning in April 1948. The goals of the United States were to rebuild war-devastated regions, remove trade barriers, modernize industry, and make Europe prosperous again.[1]"   And guess who was one of those countries, GERMANY. Yes, GERMANY. And fyi, this plan was EXTREMELY successful, helping many countries get back on their feet!¬†  America, most of the time, is there, ready to help a lending hand, to come in and stop the war, and America is ready to make peace with other countries OR help other countries make peace with each other.¬†   AND YES, THE UNITED STATES did warn¬†¬†residents of Hiroshima and Nagasaki to get out in case of impending air raids. ¬† "Before the Hiroshima bomb was dropped, the city was given the standard psychological warfare treatment prior to an ordinary incendiary attack. Leaflets were dropped on Hiroshima, indicating, along several other cities, that they were to be fire bombed within a few days and to evacuate the city. The leaflets are on display in the Peace Museum in Hiroshima and were dropped on the city several days prior to the atomic bombing. Unfortunately, most Japanese, even if they had read the leaflet, ignored the warning. Japanese citizens were instructed to turn such leaflets into their local police station."¬†  UNLIKE JAPAN WHO DID NOT warn the US about the Pearl Harbor attack, and even worse, the US was not in the WAR!! That's what dragged the US into the war actually. But if the bombings on Japan hadn't taken place, millions of people more would've died. Millions. And that is why it was decided upon.

text: The most important question in life is, ‚ÄúAm I good enough to go to Heaven?‚Äù To answer this, first you must consider what God is like. The Bible says God is Holy, just, perfect, all knowing, all powerful, full of grace and mercy; but ‚Äúwill not allow the wicked to go unpunished.‚Äù (Isaiah 6:3, Exodus 34:5-7). To see how you stand with God, compare yourself to His standard, the Ten Commandments (Exodus 20). Have you obeyed them? Here are just a few to check: "You shall have no other gods before Me." Jesus said, ‚ÄúYou shall love the Lord your God with all your heart, with all your soul, with all your mind, and with all your strength.‚Äù (Mark 12:30). Have you always put God first? If not, then you have broken this commandment. "You shall not make for yourself any graven image." You are not to make any idols and worship them instead of God. This can be a statue, self, money, family, or an incorrect concept of God. The Bible warns that idolaters will NOT enter Heaven (Ephesians 5:5). "You shall not take the name of the Lord your God in vain." Have you ever used God‚Äôs Name as a curse word? If so, then you‚Äôre a blasphemer. God promises to hold those accountable who take His Name in vain. (Deuteronomy 5:11). "You shall not murder." Jesus said if you hate your brother; then you‚Äôve murdered him in your heart (Matthew 5:22). If you‚Äôve done this, you‚Äôre a murderer and will not inherit eternal life. (1 John 3:15). "You shall not commit adultery." Jesus said, ‚Äúwhoever looks at a woman to lust for her has already committed adultery with her in his heart‚Äù (Matthew 5:28). The Bible states, ‚Äúfornicators and adulterers God will judge‚Äù (Hebrews 13:4). If you‚Äôve lusted after someone you're not married to, or had sex outside of marriage, you‚Äôre an adulterer under God‚Äôs judgment. "You shall not steal." Regardless of value, theft is taking anything that doesn't belong to you. The Bible says, ‚Äúlet him that stole steal no more: but rather let him labor‚Äù (Ephesians 4:28). Theft includes refusing to pay debts, downloading illegal software or music, or ripping people off. Thieves will NOT enter eternal life. (1 Corinthians 6:10). "You shall not bear false witness." God states that lying is an abomination (Proverbs 6:17) and ‚Äúand all liars shall have their part in the lake which burns with fire‚Äù (Revelation 21:8). If you tell even ONE lie, then you are a LIAR in God‚Äôs eyes. All have sinned, and the Bible says, "For whoever shall keep the whole law, and yet stumble in one point, he is guilty of all‚Äù (James 2:10). When we compare ourselves to God's Law, we can see that we are idolaters, blasphemers, liars, murderers, adulterers, and thieves at heart. If we're honest, we would admit that we have broken ALL of these commandments, numerous times. A Terrifying Truth The most TERRIFYING truth in the Bible is this... God is GOOD. Why is that terrifying? God is good, and we are not. Where does that leave us? Justice must be done. Imagine being guilty in court and saying to the judge, "I‚Äôm guilty but I believe you‚Äôre a good man and you will overlook my crimes," the judge would respond, "You‚Äôre right, I am a good man; and because of my goodness I‚Äôm going to see that justice is done." If God is good, He MUST punish sinners. Any sin is an infinite offence against a Holy God. God‚Äôs just punishment is called Hell (eternal flames and darkness - Mark 9:48, Matt 8:12). Because you have a conscience, every time you sinned it was with knowledge it was wrong, and this condemns you (Romans 2:15). Here is the great dilemma; the Bible says that it is evil to justify the wicked (Proverbs 17:15), so how can a Holy God justify sinners without violating justice and being evil Himself? Guilty as Charged Imagine yourself in a courtroom as a criminal, guilty of serious crimes. You are tried, convicted, and sentenced to life in prison, or a fine of a million dollars. As the guard leads you away, the judge himself then steps down and pays your fine in full. You're free to go! Though you are guilty of the crimes, your fine has been paid! Justice has been satisfied, and the judge showed himself to be both merciful AND just. That's what God did for us 2,000 years ago. God took on flesh in the person of Jesus Christ; who lived the sinless life that you could not. Then, because of His love, offered Himself on the cross, bearing the full wrath of God for our sin. Then on the third day, He rose from the dead and showed the penalty for sin being fully paid. You‚Äôre guilty, but Jesus paid the fine. The Bible says, "Christ has redeemed us from the curse of the law, having become a curse for us‚Äù (Galatians 3:13). ‚ÄúBut God demonstrates His own love toward us, in that while we were still sinners, Christ died for us‚Äù (Romans 5:8). So what should you do? God commands you to repent and put your trust in Jesus Christ ALONE for the forgiveness of sins. Abandon the thinking that your ‚Äúgood works‚Äù will help you on Judgment Day. The Bible says that our good works are like ‚Äúfilthy rags‚Äù before God. (Isaiah 64:6) They DO NOT make up for sin. Approach God like this: Imagine a woman who has committed adultery on her husband. Does her husband want a scripted apology? Of course not. Instead, her apology should be with utmost humility, sincerity, and she should determine to never even think of committing adultery again. So cry out to God; humbly asking for mercy, confessing and forsaking your sins. Read Psalm 51 to see how King David prayed to God when he sinned. The Bible says ‚ÄúBut on this one will I look: On him who is poor and of a contrite spirit, And who trembles at My word.‚Äù (Isaiah 66:2) You Must Be Born Again Jesus said, ‚Äúyou must be born again‚Äù (John 3:7). Those that repent and trust in Jesus will be born again spiritually. God will give you a new heart with new desires. The Holy Spirit will dwell in your heart and you will desire the things that please God. You'll want to grow in holiness and your knowledge of God through reading the Bible. You'll also have a desire to tell others about Jesus. Read your Bible daily and obey it. Find a Bible-preaching church, and fellowship with other believers.

text: How nauseating to see all the anti-American comments.  You people insinuating that there are never any films showing darker aspects of the US are just plain ignorant.  There are plenty of films showing the racism of the Civil Rights era, plenty of films showing corruption and plenty of films critical of US policy (ie the average Vietnam film)  So change the record. Of course if you hate America so much you can always unsubscribe from Youtube- you know since it is a US company and you don't want to be hypocrites right?  Regarding the killings of Native Americans- yes that was terrible. But is it censored? No. You can freely go into an American library and read about it and freely talk about it.  America has plenty of faults but this is just an inspirational film- its not intended to show the US is perfect.  So hypocrites how good is the freedom of speech situation in YOUR countries?  And for the record, no im not American.

text: SPECTACULAR - "Unbroken" was superb and should be on top of everyone must see list, flawless casting, cinematography and riveting and restrained acting which added layers to a foreboding and hopelessness mood. Unbroken played to a packed theater, I saw men on the edge of their seats and women recoiling in theirs, Unbroken relied less on narrative but allowed the movie to draw you in and captivate your attention through imagery, acting and engaging story telling; wisely Jolie refrained from Hollywood embellishments of a story that needed none. Wisely as well, the movie did not cover the segment after the war, to have done so in such limited time would have weakened and diluted the epic beginning, after the war should be a sequel and epic on its own. Miyavi as Watanabe nailed it and gave a chilly psychological performance with a tinge of Hannibal Lecter as an intellectual upper-class baby-faced monster, Jack as Zamperini should be nominated, he is flawlessly playing 3 different characters in one movie. Unbroken deserves a sequel (after the war) to be produced and optioned by Brad's Plan B, only than true realism and horror can be explored as in "12YAS"; we will never get the real greatness of this epic story with a Hollywood studio fronting it.with a rated pg. Kudos to Angelina for a superb film and an epic story that has been dormant for 60yrs. Footnote: Coldplay "Miracles" slay.

text: I feel like a big majority of people here are either completely ignorant on the subject of the second world war or simply american hating cunts. First of all the Japanese part of ww II was largely put in motion by the invasion of Chinese territory,  this tells us that they in fact started the war. They later conducted attacks on other countrys including the Philippines,  korea more attacks on china and etc. They also attacked major american army based situated in other country's.  The american retaliation only really started after the bombing of pearl harbour. On the topic of war crimes, though the American nuclear bomb were a very violent  approach to the  situation the Japanese had at the time enslave d and imprisoned hundreds of thousands of people, which as depicted in the book that I have In fact read lived in inhumane and more then cruel condition. They were starved and beaten which sometime lead to death. The Japanese also killed a large number of there prisoner which I remember to be around a 1/4 of all there prisoner and actually planed on killing every single one of them, but stopped by the American victory. to really comprehend  how bad a prisoner's life was read the book I can assure you, you will be bewildered to say the least. Its also truly surprising how many of them got away with it. My point beign most people including me gave little importance to the cruelty the Japanese exerted on the american POW, even if its on the same level as the holocaust but in smaller numbers. Other acts of cruelty committed by the Japanese in the prison inluded testing dangerous "things" on prisoners, mass execution, starvation, forced labour in extremely dangerous condition, severe beating/torture, stripping prisoners of all dignity and respect which would have severe impacts on the life of soldiers after they were liberated I honestly dont know what else they could have done to worsen the conditions.

text: This was a bad movie. Not in the sense of the story, or the actors they chose for the roles, but in the sense thag it moved incredibly slow. The parts that felt sad took ten minutes to get to, and by the time the sad part arrives, you don't feel sad, you just feel exhausted. I looked up the reviews before hand, saw that they were bad, but gave Ange the benefit of the doubt because I love her as a role model and an actress but, I gotta say, she can't direct. I still love her, and I still think this movie is beautiful, it just wasn't portrayed as well as it could have been. I think if they were to add more of the Japs side of the war, instead of making them seem like the worst enemies, the movie could have been phenomenal. Like everyone else, I'm still waiting for Hollywood to come out with a movie that feeds the audience with both sides and slams the audience with emotion and heartwrenchjng stories like, "Saving Private Ryan" and "Schindler's List". Both of those movies really put the audience there in the battlefield and there with the characters.

text: America. We really should all get past the idea that this is a movie solely about America. Yeah, sure it is but that's not the message they're trying to send. The movie is REALLY about one man who overcame anything and everything because he believed in something. Not about the wars in Iraq. Not about how bad America is. Not about how bad Japan was. No, it's about a man's human struggle against situations where most people would succumb to.  Forget the fact that he's American. Forget the fact that the Japanese tortured him. Forget the fact that this was during WWII. Does that matter? No because that's not the real message of the movie. So many of us Americans are so hung up on hate over ourselves and other countries because of what happened since 9/11. Instead of working for peace and moving on, we want war not just for other countries but within ourselves as well. Honestly, that's such a destructive way to cope from such a traumatizing memory.  Please, we need to at least learn to appreciate what this man has done without bringing up stuff about America. He is one man whose story needed to be known to inspire many of us who are struggling in our lives. We might think it's trivial or propaganda or whatever negative shallow things we want to believe in. But that's not the message Angelina nor the original soldier in this movie wanted to send. Very far from it. It's a movie directed by someone who felt strongly about the message it had to send, regardless if it was Angelina or not. So let's just leave it at that.

text: I was lucky enough to be an extra in this film and work alongside Angelina Jolie and Jack O'Connell. I am honoured to be a part of Louis Zamperini's heroic story. Please see this film for what it is: a story based on the courage and resilience of Louis and his fellow soldiers. It doesn't matter whether he was American, British, Australian or Swedish, what matters is the courage that he showed and how he was able to fight through the darkest of times. R.I.P. Louis Zamperini, may your soul be at rest. Thank you for inspiring so many others.¬†

text: Although the Japanese have committed war crimes on China and Korea, the United States have gotten away with many war crimes, such as racism, atomic bomb, Vietnam war, the Iraq war, and so on.   It is no surprise Americans make these movies to glorify themselves; it's the nature of Hollywood. Hollywood still has Prejudice issues, looking down at other nationality and cultures. It is no surprise too that there are history Hollywood movies do not portray themselves negatively.   The movie related to this new movie was Pearl Harbor; that was to me somehow a serious demonization of the Japanese army. It's time Hollywood does actually do something about it. Unless American media changes, perception of Americans will not change.  So to American whiners who are complaining in the comment section; face the truth. Stop being a baby, and open your small minds to take a look at the outside world.

text: This comment section is a trainwreck. Here are some actual interesting things about this movie: - Holy shit is that Jack O'Connel from Skins with black hair and an american accent? Cause that's pretty amazing. Glad to see he's doing well after the show ended. - Americans committed a large number of war crimes which, had the Allies lost, would have been condemned as such in a trial similar to that of Nuremberg. - The japanese, and the axis' forces as a whole, also committed a large number of war crimes, without a doubt more than the Allies, but not by a stretch. - Conclusion: War is awful and there are no victors in it. Nobody walks out of war with purity. All nations involved committed crimes against humanity, most soldiers involved committed acts of unrequired and unacceptable hatred, torture, violence and murder. It's not a pretty place, stop complaining about who'se the most evil, it's pointless. - The reason why people haven't made a big hollywood movie about how the allies were ALSO evil is because as a general rule people don't like to hear about their mistakes. That's how it is, there's no conspiracy there. If you want to make it yourself nobody is stopping you. Personally i'de love to see such a movie realized, and there are plenty of more indipendent movies of that sort already, not to mention some all time classics such as Platoon or Apocalypse Now which FULLY explain the horrors of war, the madness and violence of American troops and the mistakes they made. Thanks for you attention, quit your bitchin

text: Unbroken is the best movie of 2015 a must see for all, take your children,¬†and it will go down as one off the best movie about WWII. Flawless casting, masterful story telling without Hollywood embellishment, great acting/ensemble cast, superb cinematography,¬†outstanding soundtrack by Alexandre Desplat, "Miracles" by Coldplay. A gripping story that keeps you engaged, enthralled on at the edge of your seats; I've rarely seen such an engaged audience and thunderous applause at the end of the movie. It is unfathomable that a mediocre movie such as The Imitation Game should be nominated and Unbroken was not. Unbroken is a blockbuster at the box office because of word of mouth, this is how much the public love this movie. It took 60+ years to bring this film to the theaters, Congrats indeed to Angelina Jolie, crew. Roger Deakins and actors for a superb and timeless film

text: As u can see by my previous comment, i was excitied to see this movie. Honestly, the movie was disappointing to me. I felt they didnt do a good job of drawing you into the character and making you care. I wouldve liked a more fleshed out story of his youth/growing up/showing a greater bond between him and his brother or a girlfriend etc. Something to make you care. I was also disspointed that they didnt show more scenes of him over coming durring the film. I wanted some truly uplifting, fleshed out scenes. This dudes real life story was incredible. They had many great routes to take. Im not saying the movie was awful by any means, It had great production/music/acting, i just feel like they missed out on some oppurtunities and didnt make the movie as GREAT as it couldve been. Honestly, Big Hero 6 was a better more well developed movie

text: Although this is not some epic dramatic war masterpiece, i liked the movie. Jolie told Zamperini's story very well and it is a great tribute to him since he died last year. It is well directed and photographed, i thought that guy who played Louie did a good job and ¬†was very believable in his role, the script was alright, it was well paced and i was definitely interested in how much injustice he suffered in the camp - specially by that guard Watanabe. Unbroken reminded me of Forrest Gump. ¬†It is a underdog story and you root for the guy, but like i said it is not memorable and i've seen better. 3,5/5 ! It is still very enjoyable.¬†

May you rest in peace, Louie Zamperini.

text: This story is not about patriotism. It's not about Japan being the evil and U.S.A being the innocent angels. It's about the story of one man, that survived. He survived the war and he survived the traumas. Nothing is impossible. Requiescat in Pace, Louis Zamperini.

text: The diary of the Allied Forces captive in Japan. "We were given enough food" MacArthur. "Japan did not do any criminal act" "The United States advertised Japan as a criminal to the world" "However, it is the United States to have derived Japan to war" "The United States began war if the United States was driven into the situation same as Japan by other countries" The reason why this movie is criticized is to make clear fiction a historical fact. text: Here is something else some might find interesting.¬† The Japanese believe the rumor that we knew of the attack on Pearl Harbor which we didn't. According to Japan's account we caught and decoded the Japanese army's coded command of the attack.  That is only partly true as we decoded a message from the Japanese but couldn't confirm where the attack would take place. Therefore it was Japan's belief that the U.S. army prepared for the attack & let all main aircraft carriers go, only old battleships were left in the harbor. If you think I am joking I am not!!  The opinion also says that a rare vivid color film which captured the attack exists. Of course this is all false rumor. But in Japan many people know and believe the rumor. As Japan believes all rumors especially if they are coming from the government which just amazing me. Many Japanese also think the attack broke many battleships.  However that it didn't take people's lives lol. It 's completely absurd thinking, I admit. However many would be shocked how many believe this to be true. The same attitude applies to Korea & China as well as every other country Japan feels it's a victim of. Living in a bubble doesn't even begin to describe Japan accurately. :(

text: yes, war is terrible and atrocities done by people on both sides. I lived in Okinawa and know of many civilian and military deaths there in the battle of Okinawa before the big planned invasion of main islands of Japan. Reading the histories of the pacific war, most Japanese soldiers fought to the death, no surrender. Invasion of the main Japanese islands would have been a terrible bloodbath with hundreds of thousands of casaulties from fire/carpet bombing of many Japanese cities and many, many months of terrible fighting. Allies were tired of war. Germany had already surrendered. Everyone wanted a quick end to the war. Yes, the bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki was terrible. I visited Nagasaki, went to the museum, took pictures, bought the books, read the horrible personal accounts. In high school, we had to read Hiroshima in English class. But we did not read the Rape of Nanjing, stories of Korean comfort women, abuse of Allied POWs, the Bataan Death March, personal accounts of the brutal Pacific war, medical experiments on Chinese civilians, etc. War is terrible and people at that time would have done anything to end it.¬†

text: Why on earth would this movie cause anyone to say bad things about America? This movie wasn't made to shame the Japanese, it was made to educate people on this true event and share the inspiring story. Of course America has made mistakes, but so has every other country. All of the soldiers are doing what they're told and fighting for what they are told is right in every country. This man was brutally tortured by the Japanese, that is not his fault. Shame on you people who would over look all the horrible things this man went through just to point out things America has done wrong. No matter what this is still a true story, the facts are there. Show some respect. RIP Louie.

text: Every time I scroll to the comments on youtube, I think to myself: "Maybe this time there¬¥ll be some civilized, intelligent thread somewhere.", yet, every time, all I see are the same angry children and uneducated, racist nationalists looking for fights. I should probably just accept that decent people exist, but that they don¬¥t hang out on youtube.  On topic, I¬¥ve read some 60% of the book, and look forward to seeing the movie when I¬¥m finished. I feel, though, from the footage shown, that the film fails to accurately represent how decomposed the poor POW¬¥s must¬¥ve been, considering how harsh the conditions in the various camps were and how little food they were given and so on. It also, from what I can see from the trailer, fails to capture the feel of the era in which it¬¥s supposed to take place. I mean, it looks like what it is, a movie about the 30¬¥s - 40¬¥s, that is obviously crafted very recently; For contrast, Pan¬¥s Labyrinth, though fictional, captured the feel of that age much better than this film seems to do.¬†  It¬¥s really cool to see Miyavi try his hand at acting, though.

text: Why wouldn't the movie show his full 1936 Olympic stay? Although he had on of the final laps in the history of 5000 meters at the time of 56 seconds, he finished 8th. The crowd was so cheered at the athlete who would not give up that Hitler, requested to see him in his box. He shook his hand and said "ah you are the boy with the fast finish." The movie should have shown this shacking of hand and admiration by hitler. The world is not about being patriotic and Bad vs. Good. It is about everything in between. More realistic. The shacking of the hand did not make him a NAZI, he remained unbroken as an American.

text: Unbroken is the story of Louis Zamperini an Olympian who spends a harrowing 47 days in a raft with two fellow crewmen before he's caught by the Japanese navy and sent to a prisoner-of-war camp. I have to admit this film got me. I didn't think i would fall for the sentimentality , director Angelina Jolie smothered this film with , but i did.¬† It is an amazing story and Jack O'Connell is ever so impressive in the lead role.¬† The ending is very emotional and Louis Zamperini deserves such a glowing tribute.  Recommended  9 out of 10

text: How satisfying is it to know that Louie was born a year before Mutsuhiro, yet dies 11 years after Mutsuhiro. Not only does he outlive Mutsuhiro by over a decade, he's learned to reconcile with his former enemy state, eventually running a leg of the Olympics Torch relay at Nagano in 1998 and even attempting fruitlessly to reach out to Mutsuhiro, while Mutsuhiro remained the same arrogant American-hating prick in his twilight years.  Any sensible mind would know who deserves more respect.

text: Cool now I don't have to watch it because the preview told me just how predictable the storyline is and how much propaganda is pushed . Americans are always the 'good guys" who always persevere in the face of "evil" whether it be the Russians, Japanese,Germans etc . Nevermind being critical of the failed policies and owning up to the suffering at the hands of this nation. No we can't have that now can we ? That would be an inconvenient truth and make us have to reexamine who we are and what we're doing . For many it's just best to stick their patriotic heads in the sand singing Yankee doodle dandy and that we can do no wrong .  Meanwhile they hide the bodies coming home so we're not distracted by the truth or question the wisdom of the leadership and these endless wars .Go ask an Iraqi , Afghan,Syrian, Egyptian, Libyan or others how they feel about Americans .Chances are that you'll get a bad opinion of this nation because of all the suffering and destruction we've brought upon them . Also if it weren't for great sacrifices by the Russians by the millions against Germany our history might be far different .Also their battles against Japan were what made them surrender and not the two atomic bombs .Had they not taken out a big chunk of the Japanese military we would have had to invade Japan . Ask an American who won the war and they'll ignorantly tell you that it was the great USA who won the second world war and the first . Nevermind the actual facts ,just keep brainwashing the people .

text: The entire point of this movie was about Louis. It was about the endurance and free spirit he managed to keep throughout his time at the camp. Angelina Jolie wanted to create a movie where both sides were the victims, and what was in the past is in the past. Louis said it himself, forgiveness is better than revenge. Louis forgave The Bird, he forgave Japan and continued to run in Japan after the events. I think this world is missing humanity and forgiveness, if we continue to hold grudges there will only be more fighting and war; revenge will get us nowhere. I think that‚Äôs why I found this movie so inspiring, and I hope the rest of the world will eventually realize that same forgiveness as Louis. Rest In Peace Louis, you did amazing. ‚ô•Ô∏è

text: I hate to say it, but this movie is painfully *mediocre.*    From the title and the credits, you know the character will likely remain strong through all the trials that stand before him. You know he persists through his training in the Olympics and through Japanese internment during the war. But each scene just gives us a demonstration of his mental toughness through these obstacles. The character never seems like he confronts a challenge we didn't already think he was going to persist through. I mean again, we know the film is titled *Unbroken* and what the two main challenges will be in his life. We'd likely expect he'd just triumph over both of them and that's that. The importance of the narrative is to break our expectations somehow still reach that cinematic end. In that regard, the movie feels like all it did was glorify the life of Louis Zamperini without delivering a truly good story.    I'd have proposed the following changes so that, hopefully, an audience is taken more by the edge of their seat: (1) Don't title the film *Unbroken* (it's too obvious and on-the-nose) (2) Demonstrate something our character fails at miserably and which is persistent through his life despite his efforts, see this manipulated by the Japanese, then see him triumph in the end (we will have witnessed him triumphing over something we very well thought he would fail at instead of seeing him basically play out like a superhero) (3) Give us more moments of him questioning himself so we, similarly, feel like he isn't just a superhero (I feel it is painfully obvious how much Angelina Jolie reveres Louis Zamperini for how sterilized the character depiction was).     With what was a very sterilized experience, even the incredible production feels completely ornamental and over-produced. The period texture is great, the acting is great, the directing is good...but all for a story that doesn't break any of our expectations from a glorification pic.
author: Eddie Avinashi

text: My problem with this movie is that it did not properly show the story of Louis Zamparini's life. It failed to show the small acts of rebellion and humor that the POWs did to keep their spirits alive. It didn't show the incredible kindness the POWs showed to each other and the native Japanese after the war ended. It didn't show how Louie struggled after he came home and how he overcame his struggles and learned to forgive the people who had hurt him. It would have been a good movie if they had focused more on his spirit rather than just the events that occurred, and if they hadn't ended the movie when the war ended.
